author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Treasury Secretary Yellen said the U.S. economy was transitioning to ‘steady, sustainable’ growth.
description: Speaking at a news conference, Ms. Yellen said that she did not believe the U.S. was in a recession
content: President Biden and Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen on Thursday dismissed questions about whether the U.S. economy was already in a recession, pointing to the strong labor market and other metrics as signs of its health.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Yosemite’s Paradox: Cutting the Trees to Save the Park
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 28, 2022.
content: “We don’t send people out to fight hurricanes and that’s what it’s starting to feel like for firefighters.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Ramps Up Drone Exports, Signaling Global Ambitions
description: Tehran has quietly stepped up the sale of drone technology to countries outside the Middle East as it seeks to become a player in the international market.
content: Iran has made steady advances in the design and production of military drones in recent years, and has stepped up their transfer to militant groups across the Middle East as it seeks to shift the dynamics of battlefields from Yemen to Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: In This Subway Series, the Mets Did All the Flexing
description: A bad stretch for the Yankees continued with a two-game sweep in Queens. But with the most wins in baseball, a double-digit division lead and a brand-new outfielder, they remain “unfazed.”
content: The final hit on Wednesday night bounced into the glove of Aaron Hicks, and of course he didn’t want it. Hicks, the Yankees’ left fielder, gathered Starling Marte’s game-winning single, held it for a while and then flung it aside like a piece of gum. A ball boy retrieved it and tossed it into the crowd at Citi Field. Trash for the Yankees, treasure for the fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: ‘Paradise Highway’ Review: A Test of Loyalty
description: A truck driver’s brother asks her to deliver a girl to sex traffickers in order to save his life in prison.
content: Growing up in a violent home, Sally (Juliette Binoche) only had one person to rely on: her brother, Dennis (Frank Grillo).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: A Newsletter That Puts All the Pieces Together
description: The new Gameplay newsletter is fostering a community of passionate players and savvy solvers.
content: Whether you start your day with coffee and a crossword, or end it with a scramble to answer Wordle before the grid resets at midnight, the Games team at The New York Times has a challenge for you. Over the past few years, The Times has expanded its puzzle package, and with so many different games to play, solvers might have a hard time keeping track of it all. A new newsletter from the Games team is here to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Miller
title: ‘A Stone in the Mosaic’: A Director Enters the House of Wagner
description: At 33, Valentin Schwarz is taking on the monumental “Ring” cycle at the theater Wagner built for it in Bayreuth, Germany.
content: New productions of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle, a 16-hour epic taking place over four evenings, are always a highly anticipated event, and even more so when they take place at the annual Bayreuth Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: A Test Case for Australia’s Broad New Law Against Foreign Meddling
description: A donation to a hospital led to criminal charges for an Australian of Chinese descent. The case hinges not on what he did, but on what he might have been planning to do.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Australia, gripped by growing anxiety about China’s influence on its internal affairs, introduced sweeping legislation a few years ago to prevent foreign interference, but until now the laws have never been tested in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: How to Find Out Who You Are
description: Don’t just try to look inward.
content: The worst advice you can give to people trying to find themselves is to look within. That presumes a person is like an onion, with layers of social selves to peel off to get closer and closer to the inner core, the true self. The idea is that if you sit in a room with yourself and focus on yourself, you will get in touch with the “real you” or self-actualize the “real you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Medusa’ Review: Liberated Women
description: This neon-soaked feminist thriller takes aim at Brazil’s evangelical communities by depicting a girl gang that targets sinners.
content: In “Medusa,” a pop music-scored spooky story about women’s liberation, a group of churchgoing gals in Brazil play Christian Stepford Wives by day, and by night, rove the streets wearing white masks, terrorizing women they deem tramps into repentance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Mair
title: These Republican Governors Are Delivering Results, and Many Voters Like Them for It
description: Some G.O.P. governors have high public profiles, others fly below the radar — and many are excelling.
content: Republican flamethrowers and culture warriors like Donald Trump and Representatives Matt Gaetz and Marjorie Taylor Greene typically draw an outsize amount of media attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica F. Green
title: The Final Frontier Soon May No Longer Belong to All of Us
description: Russia and the U.S. both threaten international norms in outer space.
content: The Russian government has said that it will‌ withdraw from the International Space Station‌ “after 2024.” Instead of choosing multilateral cooperation, it plans to build its own station and send cosmonauts there to continue space research and exploration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Mike Pence Keeps Trying to Make Mike Pence Happen
description: It’s difficult to find a Republican strategist who will say the former vice president has a real chance in a 2024 matchup against his former boss. But he’s clearly laying the groundwork.
content: My colleague Michael Bender wrote this week about the deepening rivalry between Donald Trump and Mike Pence, onetime partners and political allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Which City Is Most Expensive for Renters? You Might Be Surprised.
description: With a spate of new luxury developments luring tenants from across the Hudson River, Jersey City has made itself the priciest city in the nation.
content: Jersey City is sometimes called the sixth borough of New York City. But right now, it can claim to be first: As of June, it was the most expensive city in which to rent a home in the United States, topping famously expensive metros like San Francisco and Miami with an average rent of $5,500, according to a report by the listing portal Rent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: In Rural America, Covid Hits Black and Hispanic People Hardest
description: At the peak of the Omicron wave, Covid killed Black Americans in rural areas at a rate roughly 34 percent higher than it did white people.
content: The coronavirus pandemic walloped rural America last year, precipitating a surge of deaths among white residents as the virus inflamed longstanding health deficits there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bonnie S. Glaser and Zack Cooper
title: Nancy Pelosi’s Trip to Taiwan Is Too Dangerous
description: She should postpone until the U.S. clarifies its Taiwan policy.
content: The United States and China are on a collision course in the Taiwan Strait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: It’s a Long Leap From Sports Team Owner to U.S. Senator
description: Alex Lasry, son of a majority owner of the Milwaukee Bucks, learned there’s a difference between making fans happy and appealing to voters.
content: MILWAUKEE — When Alex Lasry dropped out of the Democratic primary for Senate in Wisconsin on Wednesday, he said “there was no path to victory,” something no owner of a sports franchise ever wants to admit. He said he had concluded he could not beat Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes and urged voters to rally behind Barnes to defeat the Republican incumbent, Senator Ron Johnson, in November.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
description: Tania León’s piano music, John Cage’s choral works and Beethoven’s symphonies conducted by Yannick Nézet-Séguin are among recent notable recordings.
content: Tania León’s “Stride” won the 2021 Pulitzer Prize for music. While we wait for an official recording of that, we have this survey of her piano catalog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Edgar Sandoval and Elena Shao
title: When the Heat Can’t Be Beat
description: This miserable summer — monthlong heat waves, record-breaking floods, no more Choco Tacos — has left many Americans with only one option: surrender.
content: PHOENIX — Anne Morollo thought she could escape brutal summers by moving from Florida to the foothills of the Rockies three years ago. The stinging air and orange sky of her first wildfire shattered that illusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Febos
title: Memoir Writing Is Always an Act of Translation
description: From a wildfire photographer to a teenage misanthrope, these authors reflect on pain, courage and belonging.
content: The best essay collections unfold the tensions inherent in ethics, intimate relationships and art, and in the process offer a portrait of the writer’s mind. Marcia DeSanctis, an award-winning travel writer and longtime news producer, opens hers, A HARD PLACE TO LEAVE: Stories From a Restless Life (313 pp., Travelers’ Tales, $27.95), with an episode in which a younger version of herself is on assignment in Cold War Moscow. Upon returning to her room with a fever, she encounters a hotel employee named Masha — part concierge, part Kremlin informant — trying on her clothes. DeSanctis reacts with pity rather than anger and soon the interloper is toweling the guest’s forehead and tucking her in. Before departing, DeSanctis agrees to bring Masha an illustrated edition of Pushkin’s fairy tales on her next trip. For the next 20 years, she returns to the hotel with the book, doomed never to find Masha. She recalls an embrace they shared at the end of their meeting: “I had recognized her perfume — Amazone — because it had come from my own bottle.” Our narrator has made a stunning entrance, proved herself intrepid and empathetic, gifted with the dispassionate gaze of a born observer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Matthew Cullen
title: Your Friday Briefing: Biden and Xi’s Fraught Phone Call
description: Also, U.S. G.D.P. declined again and an Australian law against foreign meddling will be tested.
content: President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China spoke by phone for two hours and 17 minutes — their first direct conversation in four months during which relations between their countries have soured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: A.I. Predicts the Shape of Nearly Every Protein Known to Science
description: DeepMind has expanded its database of microscopic biological mechanisms, hoping to accelerate research into all living things.
content: In 2020, an artificial intelligence lab called DeepMind unveiled technology that could predict the shape of proteins — the microscopic mechanisms that drive the behavior of the human body and all other living things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Is My Sister Telling People About My Miscarriage?
description: A reader grapples with her sister’s cavalier treatment of personal news that was shared in confidence.
content: I had a miscarriage three weeks ago. My husband and I are gutted. Still, I was relieved (if you can call it that) that we lost the pregnancy early enough that very few people knew about it — just my mother, my sister and my best friend. I thought: At least we can grieve in private. But my sister is telling people about my miscarriage, even posting about it on social media. She says she has the right to post whatever she wants, particularly if the medical care I received may be threatened in some states. I am furious that she is broadcasting my tragedy! I want her to stop, but I don’t have the strength to fight with her now. What should I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root
title: For First Time Since 1946, New Yorkers Have Just 2 Choices for Governor
description: Changes in election law have frozen out third parties in New York State, and even Rep. Lee Zeldin couldn’t secure the Independence Party line.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — New York voters who dislike the Democrat or Republican candidates for governor have traditionally been able to cast their ballots for a long-shot candidate from any number of so-called third parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Eric Greitens’s Turbulent Political Career Stands on the Brink
description: The former Missouri governor seemed to be cruising in his comeback bid for Senate — until a late barrage of advertising called attention to his many scandals.
content: If Eric Greitens, a retired Navy SEAL and former Rhodes scholar who resigned in disgrace four years ago as governor of Missouri, loses his bid for a Senate seat in next week’s Republican primary, his defeat will be a lesson that the laws of political gravity do, in fact, still apply.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Instagram Chefs and Bakers Turning to Brick and Mortar
description: Plus: eye-catching ceramic tiles, swimwear patterned after paintings and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope Francis, Slowed by Aging, Finds Lessons in Frailty
description: On a visit to Canada, the pontiff, 85, used his own vulnerability to demand dignity and respect for older people in a world increasingly populated by them.
content: LAC STE. ANNE, Alberta — When Pope Francis landed in Canada this week, he lumbered out of a car on the tarmac, hobbled with difficulty to an awaiting wheelchair and froze in place as cameras shot at close range the spectacle of an aide adjusting the pontiff’s footrests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
title: Crops ‘Stored Everywhere’: Ukraine’s Harvest Piles Up
description: Farmers who have lived under the risk of Russian missile attacks have their doubts about an international agreement to ease a blockade on grain shipments through the Black Sea.
content: A small army of combine harvesters rolled across an endless farm field on a recent afternoon in western Ukraine, kicking dust clouds into the blue sky as the machines gathered in a sea of golden wheat. Mountains of soy and corn will be reaped in coming weeks. It will all add to a 20-million-ton backlog of grain that has been trapped in Ukraine during Russia’s grinding war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden’s Granddaughter to Hold Wedding on White House’s South Lawn
description: The rare ceremony will be the 19th documented wedding at the White House, and the first since 2013.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s eldest granddaughter, Naomi Biden, plans to get married on the South Lawn of the White House this fall in the first wedding ceremony to be held at the White House in nearly a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: There Are Holes on the Ocean Floor. Scientists Don’t Know Why.
description: Similar openings on the sea floor were first spotted 18 years ago along the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. Their origins remain unknown. Scientists are asking the public for their thoughts.
content: Deep in the waters along a volcanic ridge in the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean, sea explorers using a remotely operated vehicle to examine largely unexplored areas found a pattern of holes in the sand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Dry German Riesling: An Eternal Conundrum
description: Many people are convinced that they do not like the wines. Are they simply a niche interest, or is their obvious appeal yet to be widely understood?
content: Wine writers can be tireless, or perhaps tiresome, in recommending the virtues of perennially unloved wines.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Do I Sweat So Much in My Sleep?
description: There are many possible reasons you might wake up in a pool of perspiration. Here’s how to tell when it should be cause for concern.
content: Q: Why do I sweat in my sleep?

author: By Sandra Lim and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: Summer Terror
description: This poem subverts expectations right away and contains a peculiarity around every corner.
content: The title of this poem subverts expectations right away. After all, we associate summer with pleasure: vacations, the beach, sunshine. Each line operates in the declarative. Many lines end with a period, while others end with a semicolon, a relative of the period. Even the lines that end with commas can feel declarative: “I can smell something on them,” for example. But what’s being declared is less obvious. There’s a peculiarity around every corner: “like all flowers they look like ideas” or “Though after nine nights must come ten.” Sandra Lim’s poems often seem influenced by Louise Glück’s signature stark and stripped-down tone. What’s left is an intellectual, pale, yet strange chill. Selected by Victoria Chang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Inmates Allege They Were Raped and Assaulted After Guard Was Bribed
description: Twenty-eight women at a jail in Indiana said they were attacked after an officer provided two male inmates access to their section of the jail, according to two federal lawsuits.
content: Twenty-eight female detainees at an Indiana jail have alleged in two separate federal lawsuits that they were raped or assaulted last year by male detainees who paid a jail officer for access to keys to their cells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Annie Karni
title: After Clash, Manchin and Schumer Rushed to Reset Climate and Tax Deal
description: The West Virginia Democrat said he had relented and agreed to sign on to a climate, energy and tax package after returning to negotiations to draft a version that would combat inflation.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, and Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, were both nursing resentments when they met secretly in a windowless room in the basement of the Capitol last Monday to try to salvage a climate package that was a key piece of their party’s agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Is California Enjoying a Reprieve From Extreme Heat?
description: This summer has not yet been as hot as the last few.
content: As a heat wave baked much of the United States last week, a Bay Area meteorologist shared on Twitter a map of high temperatures expected across the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘How to Please a Woman’ Review: The Service Industry
description: A bespoke business that offers house cleaning and sex work for women is at the heart of this Australian comedy.
content: The Australian comedy “How to Please a Woman” hinges on an amusing high concept: a company that provides house cleaning and orgasms for women. This hook piques curiosity — at least enough for a coy eyebrow raise. Light intrigue is often not enough, though, and in this case, the movie strains to sustain charm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: How Los Angeles Times Handled Exposé Becomes the Talk of the Town
description: A book by a reporter from the newspaper has ignited debate about the way editors dealt with an explosive article he helped write in 2017.
content: Five years ago, Paul Pringle and Matthew Doig were on the same team. Mr. Pringle, a veteran reporter at The Los Angeles Times, and Mr. Doig, an editor at the newspaper, were working on an article that would ultimately expose the drug abuse of a powerful former dean at the University of Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Soumya Karlamangla
title: Los Angeles Enjoys Its New Bridge a Little Too Much
description: The long-awaited Sixth Street Viaduct has proved to be irresistible to pedestrians and neighborhood residents — but also graffiti artists and exhibitionist drivers.
content: LOS ANGELES — Less than three weeks ago, with fireworks, crowds and the civic joy that only a new Instagram backdrop can muster, America’s second-largest city christened a stunning new $588 million landmark: a bridge that would create a “ribbon of light” between the downtown arts district and the historic bungalows of East Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why a Vogue Cover Created a Controversy for Olena Zelenska
description: Is the magazine romanticizing war, or is the first lady weaponizing glossies?
content: Another season, another Vogue story on a politician causing a kerfuffle. After the hoo-ha over the magazine not giving Melania Trump a cover (even though Michelle Obama got three) and the to-do over Kamala Harris’s “relaxed” portrait being chosen over her more formal cover try, comes a new controversy, related to a “digital cover” released online featuring Olena Zelenska, the Ukrainian first lady.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mohsin Hamid Is Working Through Literature, From the Top
description: “About five years ago, alongside my more contemporary reading, I decided to read from back to front, historically speaking,” says the author, whose new novel is “The Last White Man.” “I began with the Sumerian ‘Instructions of Shuruppak,’ first written in cuneiform on clay tablets around 4,600 years ago.”
content: “The Story of a Brief Marriage,” by Anuk Arudpragasam, “The Bad Guys in They’re Bee-hind You!” (Bad Guys No. 14), by Aaron Blabey, “Principles for Dealing With the Changing World Order,” by Ray Dalio, and “The Last Children of Tokyo,” by Yoko Tawada. There are many more books on my wife’s night stand. Although it is precisely the same size as mine, mysteriously it also seems to be larger. She reads much more quickly than I do. We often share books, and I consider some of those on her side as also being, in a sense, on mine, but it is uncertain if she entirely feels the same, so I have not ventured to list them here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trader Joe’s workers at a Massachusetts store form a union, a milestone in the chain.
description: It is the only one of the company’s more than 500 stores with a formal union, but similar moves are afoot elsewhere.
content: Following a recent trend of service workers organizing at companies like Starbucks, Apple and Amazon, employees at a Trader Joe’s in Hadley, Mass., voted to unionize on Thursday. It is the only one of the company’s more than 500 stores with a formal union.

title: After 37 Years, the Sunny World of ‘Neighbours’ Comes to an End
description: The Australian soap opera, which has aired nearly 9,000 episodes, is drawing to a close, disappointing many fans who grew up watching the show.
content: It was during a childhood bout of the chickenpox that Jon Dew happened to tune into the first episode of “Neighbours,” a soap opera following the lives of a group of families living in a fictional cul-de-sac in Melbourne, Australia.

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Bernard Cribbins, British Actor Known for ‘Doctor Who,’ Is Dead at 93
description: Mr. Cribbins’s long career included roles on stage, film and television.
content: Bernard Cribbins, a British actor who had roles on “Doctor Who” and “Fawlty Towers,” and whose contributions to children’s programs delighted young audiences over a career that spanned seven decades, has died, his agent said on Thursday. He was 93.

title: MAGA Doesn’t Care About Cops
description: Trump pitched himself as pro-police, but when his mob stormed the Capitol, he fell silent.

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: What Is It Like to Be a Cat?
description: Playing the hit video game ‘Stray’ made me think that hyperrealism is overhyped.
content: Video game marketing, as a rule, relies on the idea that some new frontier has been breached in our journey to completely separate our brains from the dull demands of our bodies. This is true for actually groundbreaking classic games like SimCity and Braid, but also applies to games that get rereleased year after year after year with minor tweaks. As a result, an industry that has had very few widespread advances in the past 20 years ends up talking about itself in almost revolutionary terms. This is Madden like you’ve never seen it before!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Finally, a Dr. Oz Show That I Really Want to Watch
description: His campaign against John Fetterman in Pennsylvania is a consequential doozy.
content: I must have watched a few whole episodes of “The Dr. Oz Show” when I wrote a long profile of Mehmet Oz for The Times Magazine back in 2010, but afterward? Please. I’m a glutton, but not for punishment, and the snippets of the show that I’d happen upon convinced me that snippets sufficed. Oz was more huckster than healer, more showman than shaman, grinning dopily as he sacrificed his integrity on the altar of ratings. I encountered enough Faustian parables of that ilk as a journalist covering politics. I didn’t need them in my daytime television.

title: At the Serpentine, a Show of Nature’s Healing Power

content: It all started with extinction. An Extinction Marathon, actually: 12 hours of people talking about how species die out and what happens when they do. Stewart Brand, founder of the Whole Earth Catalog. Gustav Metzger, the pioneer of auto-destructive art. Adam Curtis, the British documentarian. The documentary filmmaker Laura Poitras. title: Potentially Deadly Bacteria Detected in U.S. Soil for First Time
description: The bacteria, Burkholderia pseudomallei, was found along the Gulf Coast region of Southern Mississippi. Previously, it had been detected in parts of Asia and Australia.
content: A potentially deadly bacteria was found for the first time in water and soil samples in the United States, prompting the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to alert doctors and public health experts throughout the country on Wednesday to take it into consideration when examining patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: Democratic Lawmakers Want F.T.C. to Go After Gun Ads
description: Two Democratic lawmakers are sponsoring a bill that would push the agency to scrutinize the way the gun industry markets firearms.
content: A new bill being introduced in Congress on Thursday seeks to use the powers of the Federal Trade Commission to limit the spread of guns. The bill would allow the F.T.C. to investigate gunmakers for deceptive advertising practices. That is something the agency is charged with doing for all industries, but has been reluctant to do so with gun manufacturers, which has long received extra protections from Washington, the DealBook newsletter reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Emily Flitter
title: Carried Interest Is Back in the Headlines. What Would a New Tax Proposal Do?

content: For years, Democrats and even some Republicans such as former President Donald J. Trump have called for closing the so-called carried interest loophole that allows wealthy hedge fund managers and private equity executives to pay lower tax rates than entry-level employees.

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Who Can Play the King? Questions of Representation Fuel Casting Debates.
description: Should Shakespeare’s Richard III be reserved for disabled actors? Does the character have to be played by a white man? By a man at all? Three recent productions took different tacks.
content: When three of the most prestigious Shakespeare companies in the world staged “Richard III” this summer, each took a different approach to casting its scheming title character in ways that illuminate the fraught debate over which actors should play which roles.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: This Novelist Spun an Existential Question Into a Best Seller
description: In “The Measure,” Nikki Erlick shows what happens when adults across the globe are presented with the opportunity to learn when they will die.
content: What would you do if you stepped outside one morning and found a box on your front steps — or in the hallway of your apartment building or next to your tent in the desert — containing a length of string that would indicate how long you had left to live? Would you open it, or would you toss that surprise interloper straight into the recycling bin?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Vincler
title: How to Decolonize a Museum? Try an Ax.
description: An ambitious survey of the life and art of Raphael Montañez Ortiz is at El Museo del Barrio. His work still feels subversive more than half a century after he founded the museum.
content: El Museo del Barrio has had its own internal struggles, concerning whether to focus on its Nuyorican roots or represent the Latin American diaspora more broadly. But “Raphael Montañez Ortiz: A Contextual Retrospective” proves that at its best it can do both. The ambitious exhibition turns the spotlight on the museum’s founder, who continues to make radical and compelling work at the age of 88. With this show, Montañez Ortiz’s legacy should be cemented both for his art as well as for the museum he started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How Goes the War on Inflation?
description: The news on prices is surprisingly good.
content: The U.S. economy is not currently in a recession. No, two quarters of negative growth aren’t, whatever you may have heard, the “official” or “technical” definition of a recession; that determination is made by a committee that has always relied on several indicators, especially job growth. And as Jerome Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, noted yesterday, the labor market still looks strong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: An Avant-Garde Film That Went for Laughs Instead of Scandal
description: Nothing controversial: Adolfas Mekas’s “Hallelujah the Hills,” from 1963, is romantic slapstick, with two guys competing for the same young woman.
content: The early 1960s was the golden age of underground movies. Some, like Jack Smith’s “Flaming Creatures,” provoked scandals. Others were too explicit to be written about (see Barbara Rubin’s “Christmas on Earth”). At least one was a commercial success: Adolfas Mekas’s “Hallelujah the Hills.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Rail
title: Prague Gets a Reset and the Emphasis Is Local
description: Public spaces, provocative exhibitions, new restaurants and unexpected neighborhoods offer visitors a deeper look into Czech culture.
content: Prague was justifiably popular with visitors before the pandemic, but life here often felt slightly out of whack before 2020. As a small counterbalance to an immense tragedy, the pandemic offered the city a chance for a much-needed reset. Residents had time to rediscover sites and neighborhoods that they’d long since abandoned to tourists. The sudden lack of foreign guests forced restaurant owners to refocus on customers who actually live here. Historic attractions underwent renovations. And new projects that went ahead with openings in 2020 and 2021 have made the city even more fun than before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: England Overhauls Medical Care for Transgender Youth
description: The National Health Service is closing England’s sole youth gender clinic, which had been criticized for long wait times and inadequate services.
content: The National Health Service in England announced on Thursday that it was shutting down the country’s only youth gender clinic in favor of a more distributed and comprehensive network of medical care for adolescents seeking hormones and other gender treatments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Glenn Thrush
title: F.B.I. Indicates It’s Willing to Settle Nassar Lawsuits
description: In a letter to the lawyers of the women who have sued the F.B.I., the bureau said it was “interested in considering all options to reach a resolution, including settlement discussions.”
content: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. has indicated that it is willing to settle scores of lawsuits filed against the bureau for its failure to investigate Lawrence G. Nassar, the former doctor for U.S.A. Gymnastics who was later convicted on state sexual abuse charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: 23 Easy Summer Recipes to Make You Feel Better About (Almost) Everything
description: Comfort food isn’t only for cold-weather months.
content: The sun may be shining, the birds may be chirping and the produce may be bountiful, but sometimes you need a cozy, comforting meal to fill your belly and soothe your soul. (And let’s be honest, a salad just won’t do.) Here are some dishes that celebrate summer’s best produce while also making you feel like you just took a long nap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: Like Bees of the Seas, These Crustaceans Pollinate Seaweed
description: It’s the first known case of an animal helping algae reproduce, and could suggest that pollination first evolved in the world’s ancient oceans.
content: Move over birds and bees, there is another pollinator on planet Earth, and it lives in the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Ditching the Car and Enjoying the View on a Trip to the Berkshires
description: For the first time in 50 years, a weekend train route is taking passengers directly from New York to the Berkshires. The Berkshire Flyer will run through Labor Day. Good luck getting a seat.
content: Evan Gottesman and his fiancée, Gabrielle Kleyner, were meeting friends in the Berkshires one weekend in early July. The couple, who live in Brooklyn, were trying to figure out how they would get to the rural region of western Massachusetts, which annually draws thousands of hikers, theater lovers and music aficionados with its mountains, lakes and myriad cultural centers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: A Pair of Co-ops Sold for $101 Million as the Market Returned to a Boil
description: Closings were recorded in July for two of the biggest sales so far this year, the two co-ops on the Upper East Side and a penthouse in Midtown for $75.9 million.
content: Two of New York City’s biggest sales so far this year closed in July, including a pair of co-ops sold together for $101 million by the estate of Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft who died nearly four years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: LIV Golf Comes to Bedminster, and Trump Plays Host, and 18 Holes
description: The former president’s barge-ahead style and whim for scooping up shots too hard to make wouldn’t fly on the LIV Golf series or the PGA Tour.
content: BEDMINSTER, N.J. — Walking alongside Donald Trump as he plays golf is a lot like watching his presidency: He tells you how well he’s doing, mistakes are disregarded and the one constant is an endless stream of group photos with Trump blithely flashing a toothy grin and a thumbs up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The New York Times selects Gilbert Cruz as its next Books editor.
description: Mr. Cruz has been the Culture editor at The Times since January 2018, leading coverage of arts and culture.
content: The New York Times on Thursday named Gilbert Cruz as its Books editor, handing him the task of transforming the newspaper’s book review “for the digital age.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Swing Voters, Struggling With Their Options, Scramble Traditional Political Coalitions
description: Democrats are on the defensive with vital political constituencies rattled by inflation. But amid concerns over abortion rights and democracy, Republicans still have problems in the highly educated suburbs.
content: ROCKY RIVER, Ohio — A few weeks before Ohio’s Senate primaries, Kristen Bentz stood outside a grocery store in suburban Cleveland, feeling torn about the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Ava Sasani
title: An Indiana Doctor Speaks Out on Abortion, and Pays a Price
description: Dr. Caitlin Bernard, who provided an abortion to a 10-year-old, says doctors shouldn’t be silent. But she finds herself at the center of a post-Roe clash shaking the medical community.
content: Three weeks before the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Dr. Caitlin Bernard, an Indianapolis obstetrician-gynecologist, donned her white lab coat, put her infant daughter into a front-pack baby carrier and joined a few colleagues who marched to the State Capitol, hoping to deliver a letter to Gov. Eric Holcomb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Remy Tumin
title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Highlights From Today’s G.D.P. Report
description: Inventories were a big drag on the G.D.P. number. Construction of homes and nonresidential structures declined. And federal spending fell.
content: The top-line number for U.S. gross domestic product is a composite of positive and negative forces, and the details matter:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Here are some prisoner swaps that freed Americans.
description: The possibility of the United States exchanging basketball star Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan for a Russian prisoner is reminiscent of the deals Washington has orchestrated with Moscow and others.
content: The prospect of the United States exchanging a Russian prisoner for the basketball star Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan, a former Marine, is reminiscent of the fraught deals Washington orchestrated with Moscow and its allies during and after the Cold War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Doug Mastriano says his antisemitic ally ‘doesn’t speak for me’
description: After days of criticism, the Republican candidate for governor of Pennsylvania distances himself from the founder of Gab.
content: After days avoiding questions about antisemitic remarks by a supporter of his campaign, Doug Mastriano, the Republican nominee for governor of Pennsylvania, said on Thursday that he rejected “antisemitism in any form.’’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Maria Varenikova and Michael Levenson
title: Russians, Risking Isolation in the South, Build Up for Ukrainian Attack
description: Russia is moving “maximum” forces to the south, which presents a role reversal from the eastern Donbas region: Ukraine is on the offensive and Russians holding a key city risk being cut off.
content: Ukraine has warned that Russia is racing to bolster its troops and defenses in the south, and that Kyiv still needed more weapons from the West, creating a heightened sense of urgency ahead of a looming counteroffensive to reclaim territory seized by Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: ‘It’s Scary’: Gay Men Confront a Health Crisis With Echoes of the Past
description: Monkeypox has sparked frustration and anxiety among gay and bisexual men in New York, who remember mistakes and discrimination during the early years of the AIDS crisis.
content: It was happy hour at a gay bar in Harlem, 4West Lounge, and the after-work crowd had come to drink rum punch and watch “RuPaul’s Drag Race.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Word of the Year Is ‘Uncertainty’
description: Did tech win the pandemic or not? We likely won’t be able to tell for a while.
content: More than two years into Pandemic Times, technology is more popular, stronger and richer than it was before. Or is it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Unlikely Fans of Supreme Court Ruling on Guns: Public Defenders
description: Judges in New York have so far rejected their argument that the decision should lead to the dropping of gun charges against their clients.
content: In dozens of motions filed in courthouses across New York City, public defenders are arguing that a Supreme Court ruling last month that vastly expanded gun rights has left the government without a case against their clients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: A Quirky Parisian Festival Refinds Its Footing
description: The annual Paris l’Été hosts some especially strong multidisciplinary shows this summer, one of which includes a seven-hour hike.
content: PARIS — The birds hovering around the ruins of Port-Royal des Champs, a former abbey southwest of Paris, may have been taken aback by the flock of visitors who arrived on a recent Saturday. Around 11 a.m., bleary-eyed Parisians poured out of buses for a seven-hour hike through the site and woodland that surrounds it — all in the name of theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: The Prisoner Swap
description: A deal is being negotiated to hand over a Russian arms dealer in exchange for Brittney Griner.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘DC League of Super-Pets’ Review: #ReleaseTheLassieCut
description: Dwayne Johnson and Kevin Hart voice canine heroes in a family-friendly animated spinoff of the “Justice League” franchise.
content: The animated family comedy “DC League of Super-Pets” proceeds from what can be described as a “sure, why not” premise: Superman now has a Labrador retriever named Krypto the Super-Dog, voiced by Dwayne Johnson, who fights crime and has special powers. The movie combines the conventions of a comic book blockbuster with the tropes of a talking-animal flick, making it something like “Justice League” meets “Shrek” — big, loud and full of bombastic action but with an irreverent, jocular tone. The director, Jared Stern, was a writer of “The Lego Batman Movie” (2017). Like that film, this one spends a lot of time gently mocking its superhero source material. When Lulu (voiced by Kate McKinnon), an evil guinea pig and the story’s megalomaniac villain, captures Clark Kent (John Krasinski), she ridicules the shoddy disguise of his alter ego: “A mustache, maybe, but not glasses!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Big Tech Is Proving Resilient as the Economy Cools
description: Tech companies are slowing their frenetic hiring, but a combination of dominance and diversity is turning out to be — yet again — an overwhelming asset.
content: No boom can last forever, even for the technology industry’s most affluent companies. Investors punished the biggest tech companies earlier this year, erasing $2 trillion in market value over fears the industry would falter in the face of rising inflation and a slowing economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Hey, LIV Golf. Charles Barkley Is Waiting for Your Call.
description: The TNT basketball analyst has been a loud supporter of the Saudi-backed golf series. On Thursday, he gave Greg Norman, LIV’s chief executive, 24 hours to offer him a job.
content: BEDMINSTER, N.J. — Charles Barkley has a question for people wondering why anyone would associate with the Saudi-backed LIV Golf tour: Why aren’t they outraged by all the other American companies doing business with the same controversial wealth management fund, which is overseen by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘A Love Song’ Review: When Moving Forward Means Looking Back
description: Two former childhood friends rekindle their connection in this sweetly hopeful story of romantic longing.
content: Framed by soaring mountains and a gleaming lake somewhere in Southwestern Colorado, a woman (Dale Dickey), wiry and weathered, catches crayfish and waits in her small camper for a special someone to arrive. The woman is Faye and, like Lito (Wes Studi), the childhood friend she hopes will respond to her invitation, she is long widowed. Maybe he, too, is ready for some company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Vengeance’ Review: A Dish Best Served With Frito Pie
description: In this comedic culture-war thriller, B.J. Novak, who wrote and directed, plays an aspiring podcaster chasing a true-crime story in West Texas.
content: Ben Manalowitz, who writes for The New Yorker (he’s played by B.J. Novak, who has been published in its pages), wants to break into podcasting. “Not every white guy in America needs to have a podcast,” someone tells him, but this white guy sees the platform as a perfect stage for his ambitions and his big thoughts about America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Sharp Stick’ Review: The Babysitter’s Schlubs
description: Lena Dunham’s new movie follows a 26-year-old who methodically gains sexual experience after having an uncomfortable affair.
content: Sarah Jo (Kristine Froseth), the mythical seductress at the center of “Sharp Stick,” an uneven, uneasy fable of desire by the writer, director and performer Lena Dunham, is the kind of erotic nymph who exists only in Penthouse letters and vintage soft-core movies. A babysitter long of hair and limb but short on emotional demands, Sarah Jo ventures through modern day Los Angeles in modest floral pinafores, which she lifts above her waist in invitation. No need for conversation or dinner — she only appears to eat plain yogurt, anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: Needing a Bat, the Yankees Trade for Andrew Benintendi
description: With Giancarlo Stanton injured, Benintendi, a high-contact hitter, will fill an immediate gap. He says he is “open-minded” to being vaccinated against Covid-19.
content: After weeks of speculation, Andrew Benintendi is heading to the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: China’s Domestic Troubles Will Hang Over Biden-Xi Call
description: Some American officials suspect that what is really driving China’s president to lash out recently is a desire to divert attention from his economic and pandemic problems at home.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Biden gets on a call with President Xi Jinping of China on Thursday to try to tamp down tension over Taiwan, the two will have a laundry list of mutual grievances to address. But one source of recent friction may be something not on the list: China’s domestic troubles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Blue Island’ Review: In Hong Kong, the Past Is Present
description: In this hybrid of documentary and dramatization, real-life Hong Kong students re-enact the struggles of activists from earlier generations.
content: In “Blue Island,” a hybrid of documentary and dramatization from the director Chan Tze Woon, real-life students from contemporary Hong Kong perform re-enactments of the political struggles of previous generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Resurrection’ Review: Mother of Fears
description: A successful single mother encounters a terrifying man from her past in this crazily enjoyable horror movie.
content: Somewhere near the end of “Resurrection,” a sleek, hurtling, ridiculously entertaining horror movie from Andrew Semans, there’s a scene of such gruesomely bonkers intent that I actually gasped. And then I laughed, tickled by how easily Semans and his star, the charismatic Rebecca Hall, had persuaded me to invest in their lunatic shenanigans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Who Is ‘Wagatha Christie’? Let Us Explain.
description: A feud between two television personalities made its way to a London courtroom. A verdict is due on Friday.
content: A version of this article was first published in May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: How to Cook in a Vacation Rental (and Still Enjoy Your Vacation)
description: The most enjoyable meals on a trip may just be the ones you make yourself with these tips for planning, shopping and using up every ingredient.
content: The collective desire — desperation? — to get away has risen, as have the prices of food and travel, so you should spend each moment of vacation exactly as you’d like. While eating out is its own form of sightseeing, cooking some or all meals in a vacation rental can be as enjoyable as it is convenient, flexible and economical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
title: 2016 Campaign Looms Large as Justice Dept. Pursues Jan. 6 Inquiry
description: Top officials at the department and the F.B.I. appear intent on avoiding any errors that could taint the current investigation or provide ammunition for a backlash.
content: As the Justice Department investigation into the attack on the Capitol grinds ever closer to former President Donald J. Trump, it has prompted persistent — and cautionary — reminders of the backlash caused by inquiries into Mr. Trump and Hillary Clinton during the 2016 presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and April Rubin
title: 8 Dead as Flash Flooding Swamps Parts of Kentucky
description: The National Guard was mobilizing to rescue people from homes and rooftops in what Kentucky’s governor said was one of the “most devastating flooding events” in state history.
content: At least eight people died and others were rescued from rooftops on Thursday after heavy rains across southeastern Kentucky touched off what the governor said was “one of the worst, most devastating flooding events” in state history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Shell reports record profit, again, with $11.5 billion in latest quarter.
description: The energy giant is thriving because of soaring oil and gas prices and a tight market for refined products.
content: Shell reported record earnings for the second consecutive quarter on Thursday, as the energy giant continues to prosper from high oil and gas prices spurred by the war in Ukraine and other factors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: JetBlue and Spirit announce plan to merge, creating fifth-largest U.S. airline.
description: The deal, which values Spirit at $3.8 billion, was announced a day after Frontier’s bid for Spirit fell apart. It is likely to face antitrust scrutiny.
content: JetBlue Airways reached a deal to buy Spirit Airlines on Thursday, a merger that could reshape the airline industry by putting pressure on the nation’s four dominant carriers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Patricia Cohen
title: They Flocked to China for Boom Times. Now They’re Thinking Twice.
description: Global businesses and industries that rode the China growth wave for years are bracing for the fallout of a slowing economy.
content: A.H. Beard, a 123-year-old luxury mattress manufacturer based in Australia, started eyeing China around 2010. At the time, the family-owned company faced looming competition from low-cost, foreign-made mattresses in its home market. China, with its 1.4 billion consumers and a growing middle class with a taste for premium brands, seemed like a good place to expand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Alan Yuhas
title: Russian Arms Dealer in Proposed Swap for Brittney Griner Has Notorious History
description: Viktor Bout has been accused of supplying arms to Al Qaeda, the Taliban, and rebels in Rwanda. His exploits helped inspire a 2005 film, “Lord of War,” that starred Nicolas Cage.
content: Shortly after his conviction in 2011 on charges including conspiring to kill American citizens, the Russian arms dealer Viktor Bout relayed a defiant message through his lawyer, even though he faced the prospect of decades in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Sheila Rayam Is Named Executive Editor of The Buffalo News
description: Ms. Rayam, 55, the first Black journalist to lead the paper, will take over as its community still reels from one of the deadliest racist massacres in recent American history.
content: A Black woman is taking the helm of Buffalo’s daily newspaper as the city still grieves the racist supermarket massacre that shocked the city this year just as its economy and population showed signs of recovering from decades of economic decline.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 28, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 28, 2022.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about six American authors nominated for this year’s Booker Prize misstated the former eligibility criteria for the prize. Before 2014, it was open to authors from Britain, Ireland, the Commonwealth and Zimbabwe, not only to authors from Britain and Ireland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
title: Democrats’ Plan to Fight Inflation May Lower Costs Over Time
description: A package of tax increases, lower drug prices and other provisions aimed at reducing the federal budget deficit could alleviate rapid price gains.
content: President Biden said on Thursday that an energy, tax and health care agreement reached with Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia would relieve inflation and bring down the cost of living for American families. That key promise helped bring the centrist senator on board for a bill that carries the remnants of the president’s expansive domestic agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jessica Cheung, Will Reid, Rachelle Bonja, Liz O. Baylen, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: How Expecting Inflation Can Actually Create More Inflation
description: By raising interest rates, the Federal Reserve hopes to prevent consumers from believing higher prices will last forever.
content: To fight historic levels of inflation, the Federal Reserve this week, once again, raised interest rates, its most powerful weapon against rising prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Satin Sheets
description: A couple disagrees about which side should go up.
content: Renee writes: My husband and I have a debate about how to put our satin sheets on the bed. He claims the sheets should go on “the way they’re meant to,” meaning the silky side faces up. I say they should be flipped so that the softer side is on top of us. Who’s right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Hansan: Rising Dragon’ Review: Naval Gazing
description: The dutiful Korean war movie “Hansan: Rising Dragon” recounts a spectacular 16th-century naval victory over Japanese invaders.
content: The dutiful war movie “Hansan: Rising Dragon” recounts the successes of the 16th-century Korean national hero Yi Sun-shin, which were previously chronicled in the 2014 film “The Admiral: Roaring Currents.” Directed by Kim Han-min, both films trumpet Admiral Yi’s savvy and courage in fending off the Japanese invaders attempting to conquer the peninsula. This time, the main event is the Battle of Hansan Island in 1592, a Korean victory that is showcased as a feat of both strategy and technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Jane Perlez
title: Biden and Xi Conduct Marathon Call During Time of Rising Tensions
description: White House officials characterized the call, which lasted two hours and 17 minutes, as a relationship-tending mission.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China confronted each other over Taiwan during a marathon phone call on Thursday, but neither side reported any concrete progress on that longstanding dispute or any of the other issues that have flared between the two powers in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Honor Society’ Review: Ivy League Strategist’s Cynical Shell Is Cracked
description: Angourie Rice plays an initially unappealing character, as a Harvard striver with sneaky moves.
content: There’s a species of Young Adult novels — and their attendant film adaptations — that wears sophistication on its sleeve. Mostly for the purpose of demonstrating that sophistication won’t save the anguished teenage soul — see “The Perks of Being a Wallflower.” In the teen rom-com, sophistication usually manifests itself in a near-endless stream of pop culture references.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Heffalumps and Woozles
description: Bill Pipal makes his New York Times Crossword debut in a collaboration with veteran constructor Jeff Chen.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I’ve said many times that I love a theme with a lot of layers. As you peel them away, each layer hopefully makes you say, “Oh. Ooh,” as everything sinks in. The puzzle doesn’t give up its secrets easily, but that’s what makes it fun. The thrill of figuring things out lasts through the entire time you’re solving, almost like a cruciverbal version of Willy Wonka’s Everlasting Gobstopper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: The Role of Art in a Time of War
description: Painting will not stop missiles. Music will not end suffering. But culture is not powerless — and a visit to Ukraine reaffirmed what it can do at its best.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — You do not have to go far outside of Kyiv to see how the massacre of civilians and the trampling of culture still come one after the other. In Borodianka, a nucleus of Russian atrocities about 45 minutes north of here — the drive is slower now that the bridges have been demolished — the Palace of Culture has had its windows blown out; its concert hall is dust-caked, and the ticket booths have been ripped asunder. Halfway between the capital and the Belarusian border, I had to contort my body through twisted studs to enter the leveled Ivankiv Historical and Local History Museum, its statuary now pitted, its embroideries scorched. It is far worse further east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Shao
title: Seven Key Provisions in the Climate Deal
description: The $369 billion climate and tax bill would affect every aspect of U.S. energy production, with incentives for producers and consumers to move away from fossil fuels.
content: The climate and tax deal announced by Senate Democrats on Wednesday would pump hundreds of billions of dollars into programs designed to speed the country’s transition away from an economy based largely on fossil fuels and toward cleaner energy sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Britain’s Power Grid Warns of a Tight Energy Supply This Winter
description: Unlike many European countries, Britain produces substantial amounts of its own gas, but it has still faced skyrocketing energy prices in recent months.
content: Britain’s power grid raised the prospect of a tight energy supply this winter, publishing an unusual early forecast to help the energy industry prepare for strains over the winter related to the fallout from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Noah Weiland
title: Health Secretary Says States ‘Need to Work With Us’ on Fighting Monkeypox
description: The suggestion that states need to do more seemed to startle state and local officials, who said in interviews that they are generally satisfied with the federal government’s response.
content: WASHINGTON — With monkeypox cases on the rise and vaccine doses in scarce supply, President Biden’s health secretary suggested on Thursday that states and localities bear some of the responsibility for what critics have called a flawed response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Skeleton of a Gorgosaurus Sells at Auction for $6.1 Million
description: The sale was the latest in a series of dinosaur-fossil auctions that have infuriated paleontologists who worry about the commercialization of Earth’s evolutionary history.
content: A robust skeleton of a Gorgosaurus, a Tyrannosaurus rex relative that roamed the Earth about 80 million years ago, sold at a Sotheby’s auction on Thursday for $6.1 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lora Kelley
title: Newsmax renews deal to be carried by Verizon’s Fios, days before rival OAN is to be dropped.
description: Both Newsmax and OAN are known for their loyalty to Donald Trump, and for serving as platforms for his debunked claims of rampant voter fraud in 2020.
content: Newsmax, a news network that amplified the falsehood that the 2020 presidential election had been rigged against Donald J. Trump, reached a deal to continue to be distributed by Verizon’s Fios network just days after the telecom company said it was dropping another right-wing broadcaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger, Margot Sanger-Katz, Claire Cain Miller and Eve Washington
title: States With Abortion Bans Are Among Least Supportive for Mothers and Children
description: They tend to have the weakest social services and the worst results in several categories of health and well-being.
content: In Mississippi, which brought the abortion case that ended Roe v. Wade before the Supreme Court, Gov. Tate Reeves vowed that the state would now “take every step necessary to support mothers and children.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Kornelis
title: Sona Movsesian Leans on The Rock, Cher and Mister Rogers
description: The co-host of “Conan O’Brien Needs a Friend” talks about the best Girl Scout cookies and adulting at Disneyland.
content: “The World’s Worst Assistant,” a new memoir by Sona Movsesian, recounts what happens when an ambitious young woman who excelled at both the Burger King drive-through and the NBC page program managed to turn things around when she landed a job as Conan O’Brien’s assistant — a deal she sealed by asking if she could lie down during the interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon posts 7.2 percent increase in revenue, the slowest growth rate in two decades.
description: Growth has slowed from its pandemic highs as people return to shopping in-person and pull back on spending in an uncertain economy.
content: Amazon’s growth continued to come down from its pandemic highs, the company said on Thursday, signaling a new normal as online shopping resets amid a tumultuous economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Should Red Wines Be Served Cool?
description: The proper serving temperature is nuanced, depending on the style of the wine, the vintage, the weather and your own personal taste.
content: Wine is a joyous, never-ending education, as I relearn every month in Wine School. Even so, the lessons were humbling to me over the last few weeks as we examined how serving temperature affects red wines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: West Virginia Punishes Banks That It Says Don’t Support Coal
description: The move to exclude the institutions from state business is part of a growing effort by Republican officials to shut out companies that are backing away from fossil fuels.
content: West Virginia on Thursday morning announced that five major financial institutions, including Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan, would be barred from doing business with the state because they have stopped supporting the coal industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: U.S. Economy Shows Another Decline, Fanning Recession Fears
description: Gross domestic product, in an initial reading, fell 0.2 percent in the second quarter. President Biden said any troubles would be transitory.
content: A key measure of economic output fell for the second straight quarter, raising fears that the United States could be entering a recession — or perhaps that one had already begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Hypochondriac’ Review: A Mother of All Breakdowns
description: A son tries to escape the fate of his mom in this psychological thriller.
content: In the psychological thriller “Hypochondriac,” life and all its horrors begin with Mother. When the film’s protagonist, Will (played as a child by Ian Inigo), was young, his mother (Marlene Forte) suffered from psychosis. Her illness manifested in intense, violent spells. She would scream and hurt herself. One of Will’s most indelible memories is of his mother strangling him as a boy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Tim Giago, Native American Newspaperman, Is Dead at 88
description: The founder of the first independent American Indian newspaper braved gunshots and firebombs to provide an unvarnished look at life on the reservation.
content: Tim Giago, the outspoken founder of the first independently owned Native American newspaper in the United States, who challenged discriminatory government policies, American Indian stereotypes in popular culture and, at times, tribal leaders themselves, died on Sunday in Rapid City, S.D. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Climate Change Worsened Britain’s Heat Wave, Scientists Find
description: Scorchers like the one last week are still unusual, but global warming is making them more likely, and worse when they do strike.
content: The heat that demolished records in Britain last week, bringing temperatures as high as 104.5 degrees Fahrenheit to a country unaccustomed to scorching summers, would have been “extremely unlikely” without the influence of human-caused climate change, a new scientific report issued Thursday has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Domestic opposition to Putin invites jail, dividing activists over the wisdom of staying put to fight.
description: Shortly after Russia shocked the world by attacking Ukraine on Feb. 24, Ilya V. Yashin, a local Moscow councilman and prominent opposition figure, decided it was time to see a dentist.
content: Shortly after Russia shocked the world by attacking Ukraine on Feb. 24, Ilya V. Yashin, a local Moscow councilman and prominent opposition figure, decided it was time to see a dentist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Not Okay’ Review: Posting Through It
description: In this social media satire, a young woman desperate to find her purpose executes a heinous hoax.
content: In our era of branding and ubiquitous social media, where posts masquerade as life stories and mere traits become entire identities, it can feel inadequate — even impossible — to just be yourself. That’s how Danni Sanders, the ditsy antiheroine played by Zoey Deutch in “Not Okay,” becomes the most hated person on the internet. She can’t be just an upper-class 20-something living in “J train Bushwick,” so she pretends to be a survivor of a terrorist attack. As satires go, this one by the writer and director Quinn Shephard is hardly subtle — but though it lacks narrative finesse, “Not Okay” is brimming with provocative in-jokes for the extremely online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: ‘A Balance’ Review: Critical Distance
description: Yujiro Harumoto’s slow-build morality tale puts an ambitious documentary maker in an uncomfortable position as her life begins to resemble her films.
content: About an hour into Yujiro Harumoto’s knotty and suspenseful morality tale “A Balance,” Yuko (Kumi Takiuchi), a documentary director, argues with an abortion doctor (Ryo Ikeda) that “What’s moral isn’t always what’s best.” It’s a platitude that has already been tested for Yuko, whose life has become suddenly very complicated. But that test is only beginning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaha Nailah Avery
title: Where Rihanna Got Her Style Groove
description: An insider look at Crop Over, the Barbadian equivalent of Carnival, an annual celebration of music and heritage — and amazing outfits.
content: It was midafternoon in Barbados, and a tall gate swung open onto a wide yard. Lauren Austin led the way through her home-turned-costume-production factory, stepping around a dozen four-foot-tall wings, their fuchsia feathers stretching out across the floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin and Jesus Jiménez
title: 4,000 Mistreated Beagles Need Homes. These Folks Are Stepping Up.
description: The dogs were headed for testing labs and didn’t even have names or know how to play. Volunteers are introducing them to grassy yards and cuddly movie nights for the first time.
content: Hazel, a 6-year-old beagle, got scared her first night in a foster home when she played with a toy and it squeaked. She had never seen a stuffed animal or ball before. She was comfortable with water but afraid of the tub during her first bath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: ‘Negligent and Sexist’: Why Rape Survivors Asked Feds to Investigate N.Y.P.D.
description: Letters from victims and activists drew the Justice Department’s attention after city and state officials failed to act on the same complaints.
content: By the time the U.S. Justice Department announced last month that it would investigate the New York Police Department’s handling of sex crimes, rape survivors and victim advocates had spent years pushing city and state officials to act.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Names Thomas Sondergard as Music Director
description: The Danish conductor succeeds Osmo Vänskä, who led the ensemble through the most tumultuous period in its history.
content: The Minnesota Orchestra, after the departure of a longtime leader who shepherded the ensemble through the most tumultuous period in its history, announced on Thursday that the Danish conductor Thomas Sondergard would become its next music director.

title: This 150-Year-Old Mining Law Hurts Taxpayers and the Environment
description: It’s time for an overhaul.
content: In 1872, seven years after the end of the Civil War, Ulysses S. Grant was president, John Wesley Powell was completing his second expedition down the Colorado River, and Congress was dispatching another party to map areas of the Southwest. Most Western territories were years away — or, in New Mexico’s case, decades away — from statehood.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Surprise Deal Would Be Most Ambitious Climate Action Undertaken by U.S.
description: The announcement Wednesday of an agreement in the Senate almost instantly reset the role of the United States in the global effort to fight climate change.
content: WASHINGTON — The $369 billion climate and tax package forged in a surprise deal by Senate Democrats would be the most ambitious action ever taken by the United States to try to stop the planet from catastrophically overheating.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Daniel Snyder Answers Congress’s Questions About Commanders Harassment Claims

content: The Washington Commanders owner Daniel Snyder testified Thursday in front of a congressional committee that has been investigating widespread allegations of workplace misconduct at his team, including claims from former staff members that directly accused him of inappropriate behavior.

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: In Savannah, Spanish Moss, Tea Roses and Murder
description: The rot runs deep in George Dawes Green’s long-awaited fourth novel.
content: Around these parts, the publication of a new George Dawes Green novel is an event. Partly because he publishes so rarely — four novels in 28 years — and partly because each book inhabits a distinct world and space, be it a cave in Manhattan’s Inwood Park (his brilliant 1994 debut, “The Caveman’s Valentine”), a courtroom (“The Juror,” released the following year) or the mad desperation surrounding lottery winners (2009’s “Ravens”).

title: With Beijing and Washington at odds over Russia, China’s domestic issues hang over a Biden-Xi call.
description: When President Biden gets on a call with President Xi Jinping of China on Thursday to try to tamp down tension over Taiwan, the two will have a laundry list of mutual grievances to address. But one source of recent friction may be something not on the list: China’s domestic troubles.

title: The Magic of Pizza Bread Crumbs

content: I drove to Andy’s Orchard in Morgan Hill, Calif., the other day to pick peaches, plums, apricots and nectarines. Some were ready to eat right off the tree, drippy and warmed from the sun, and the rest I brought home. I keep making excuses to walk through the kitchen now, to lean in and huff their perfume like some kind of creep. I love stone fruit, OK?

content: The U.S. offered a prisoner swap to Russia: Viktor Bout, a notorious Russian arms dealer, for Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. star, and Paul Whelan, a former Marine.

author: By Beandrea July
title: ‘Ali & Ava’ Review: Don’t You Want to Sing Along?
description: Even as this romantic drama clings uncomfortably to the surface of an interracial relationship, the movie still delivers pops of color and memorable melodies, our critic writes.
content: In “Ali & Ava” the writer-director Clio Barnard (“The Arbor,” “The Selfish Giant”) leans into the emotional alchemy of an unexpected romance between Ali (Adeel Akhtar), a British-Pakistani D.J. who has recently separated from his wife, and Ava (Claire Rushbrook), an Irish-British teacher and mother of four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Oresteia’ Review: A Mother’s Grief, Underestimated
description: Anastasia Hille is riveting as Klytemnestra in Robert Icke’s production of “Oresteia” at the Park Avenue Armory.
content: Before the first domino of their tragedies falls, before murder begets murder begets murder, they are an enchanting family: the mother, Klytemnestra, warm and easy with her two little ones gathered close around her; the father, Agamemnon, suave in public but playful the instant he walks through the door at the end of the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Deal, for Now
description: Joe Manchin’s climate announcement has the potential to be a very big deal.
content: Many parts of federal policy shift back and forth over time. Taxes rise and fall, as do spending on anti-poverty programs and the military. If a package of policies doesn’t pass one year, it might pass in a future year, and the long-term trajectory of the United States probably won’t be affected much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, David F. Gallagher and Jenny Gross
title: The Fed Won’t Say the ‘R’ Word
description: Chair Jerome Powell was asked in every way possible whether the economy was in, or headed toward, a recession.
content: The Federal Reserve is continuing its aggressive campaign to cool inflation, even as the economy begins to slow. The U.S. central bank raised interest rates yesterday — this time by three-quarters of a percentage point — for the fourth time this year. Investors cheered the move, with the S&P 500 rising nearly 3 percent by the end of the day. Futures markets suggest stocks will open slightly lower today. The Fed’s benchmark short-term interest rate is now as high as 2.5 percent, up from near-zero in March.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Gurnah, who received the Nobel Prize in Literature last year, often deals with themes of exile and displacement in his writing. His latest novel, set in East Africa under German rule in the 1900s, follows three characters: Ilyas, who joins the German troops; his sister, Afiya, who is raised by his best friend after he leaves; and Hamza, another former soldier who returns from the war and falls in love with Afiya.

content: There are certain sounds that will forever evoke the 1990s in our collective sense memory. The opening guitar riff of Nirvana’s “Smells Like Teen Spirit.” The chimes of a dial-up modem. The persistent, grating laughter of Beavis and Butt-Head.

content: With glossy yellow rings bull’s-eyed by neon red cherries, pineapple upside-down cake is a beloved American dessert: homey, nostalgic, boldly geometric. Ever since the recipe was popularized in the 1920s, it’s become so entrenched in our confectionary consciousness that an upside-down cake made with anything else seems like a mere afterthought.

They had come from three weeks of rest and were back in company class, preparing for a tour in upstate New York.
